members.member:
Copied from Pcap.Net @ 20091117
Code constants for well-defined ethernet protocols. EtherType is a two-octet field in an Ethernet frame, as defined by the Ethernet II framing networking standard. It is used to indicate which protocol is encapsulated in the payload. Also contains entries taken from linux/if_ether.h and tcpdump/ethertype.h

member.summary: Indicates that this fragment is a retransmission of a previously transmitted fragment. (For receiver to recognize duplicate transmissions of frames)

member.summary: Indicates the power management mode that the station will be in after the transmission of the frame

member.summary: Indicates that there are more frames buffered for this station

member.name: P:PacketDotNet.Ieee80211FrameControlField.Order
member.summary: Bit is set when the "strict ordering" delivery method is employed. Frames and fragments are not always sent in order as it causes a transmission performance penalty.

member.name: T:PacketDotNet.Ieee80211MacFields
member.summary: See http://www.ucertify.com/article/ieee-802-11-frame-format.html NOTE: All positions are not defined here because the frame type changes whether some address fields are present or not, causing the sequence control field to move. In addition the payload size determines where the frame control sequence value is as it is after the payload bytes, if any payload is present

member.summary: Reads a 7-bit encoded integer from the stream. This is stored with the least significant information first, with 7 bits of information per byte of value, and the top bit as a continuation flag. This method is not affected by the endianness of the bit converter.

member.name: M:MiscUtil.IO.EndianBinaryReader.ReadBigEndian7BitEncodedInt
member.summary: Reads a 7-bit encoded integer from the stream. This is stored with the most significant information first, with 7 bits of information per byte of value, and the top bit as a continuation flag. This method is not affected by the endianness of the bit converter.
member.returns: The 7-bit encoded integer read from the stream.

member.name: M:MiscUtil.IO.EndianBinaryReader.ReadString
member.summary: Reads a length-prefixed string from the stream, using the encoding for this reader. A 7-bit encoded integer is first read, which specifies the number of bytes to read from the stream. These bytes are then converted into a string with the encoding for this reader.
member.returns: The string read from the stream.

member.name: T:PacketDotNet.IPv4Packet.TypesOfService_Fields
member.summary:
Type of service code constants for IP. Type of service describes how a packet should be handled.
TOS is an 8-bit record in an IP header which contains a 3-bit precendence field, 4 TOS bit fields and a 0 bit.
The following constants are bit masks which can be logically and'ed with the 8-bit IP TOS field to determine what type of service is set.
Taken from TCP/IP Illustrated V1 by Richard Stevens, p34.

member.name: T:PacketDotNet.LinkLayers
member.summary:
Link-layer type codes.
Taken from libpcap/bpf/net/bpf.h and pcap/net/bpf.h.
The link-layer type is used to determine what data-structure the IP protocol bits will be encapsulated inside of.
On a 10/100mbps network, packets are encapsulated inside of ethernet. 14-byte ethernet headers which contain MAC addresses and an ethernet type field.
On ethernet over ppp, the link-layer type is raw, and packets are not encapsulated in any ethernet header.

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.PPPoECode.ActiveDiscoveryInitiation
member.summary: From RFC2516: The Host sends the PADI packet with the DESTINATION_ADDR set to the broadcast address. The CODE field is set to 0x09 and the SESSION_ID MUST be set to 0x0000. The PADI packet MUST contain exactly one TAG of TAG_TYPE Service- Name, indicating the service the Host is requesting, and any number of other TAG types. An entire PADI packet (including the PPPoE header) MUST NOT exceed 1484 octets so as to leave sufficient room for a relay agent to add a Relay-Session-Id TAG.

member.summary: A Chassis Identifier
member.description: A mandatory TLV that identifies the chassis containing the IEEE 802 LAN station associated with the transmitting LLDP agent

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.LLDP.TLVTypes.PortID
member.summary: A Port Identifier
member.description: A mandatory TLV that identifies the port component of the MSAP identifier associated with the transmitting LLDP agent.

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.LLDP.TLVTypes.TimeToLive
member.summary: Specifies the Time to Live
member.description: Indicates the number of seconds that the recipient LLDP agent is to regard the information associated with this MSAP identifier to be valid A value of 0 signals that this source is no longer available and all information associated with it should be deleted.

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.LLDP.TLVTypes.PortDescription
member.summary: A Description of the Port
member.description: The port description field shall contain an alpha-numeric string that indicates the ports description.

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.LLDP.TLVTypes.SystemName
member.summary: The System's Assigned Name
member.description: The System Name TLV allows network management to advertise the systems assigned name.

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.LLDP.TLVTypes.SystemDescription
member.summary: A Description of the System
member.description: The System Description TLV allows network management to advertise the systems description

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.LLDP.TLVTypes.SystemCapabilities
member.summary: A bitmap containing the System's capabilities
member.description: The System Capabilities TLV is an optional TLV that identifies the primary function(s) of the system and whether or not these primary functions are enabled.

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.LLDP.TLVTypes.ManagementAddress
member.summary: The Management Address
member.description: The Management Address TLV identifies an address associated with the local LLDP agent that may be used to reach higher layer entities to assist discovery by network management.

member.name: F:PacketDotNet.LLDP.TLVTypes.OrganizationSpecific

member.description: This TLV category is provided to allow different organizations, such as IEEE 802.1, IEEE 802.3, IETF, as well as individual software and equipment vendors, to define TLVs that advertise information to remote entities attached to the same media.
